questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the casualty with severe chest pain. ECG was suggestive of anterior wall ST elevation MI. He underwent thrombolysis with reteplase with good resolution of ECG changes. On day 3, he developed sharp chest pain, worse with inspiration and movement and improved with NSAIDs. On day 5, the patient has progressive dyspnea. His heart rate was 110/min, BP was 90/50 mmHg with elevated JVP. What is the most likely complication that has occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Although post-MI pericarditis (Dressler's syndrome) (Option A) presents with sharp pleuritic chest pain improved by NSAIDs, the new hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated JVP on day 5 indicate cardiac tamponade from rapid pericardial fluid accumulation.
  • Cardiac tamponade can occur as a rare complication in post-MI patients. It is the rapid accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac under pressure.
  • The typical clinical triad seen in tamponade is 'Beck's triad'
    • Hypotension
    • Distended neck veins
    • Muffled heart sounds
  • The development of acute mitral regurgitation (Option B) or VSD is associated with severe pulmonary oedema and is less likely to be associated with chest pain.
  • Rupture of the ventricular free wall (Option D) is the underlying event causing hemopericardium in tamponade. The clinical syndrome is tamponade rather than just rupture.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man is referred with a 6-month history of progressive exertional dyspnoea and pedal oedema. There is no associated chest discomfort. He is a reformed smoker and a non-alcoholic. His father died of a myocardial infarct at the age of 55 years. Blood pressure is 150/86 mmHg. Results of investigations are as follows: HbA1C of 6.1%; LDL-cholesterol 160 mg/dl; ECG shows sinus rhythm; Echocardiogram showed dilated and impaired left ventricular function with ejection fraction of 30%, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation and no LVH. What is the most likely underlying aetiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic heart failure is not an absolute diagnosis, and an etiological evaluation is mandatory. Ischemic cardiomyopathy accounts for over half of chronic heart failure cases. This patient's dyslipidemia, hypertension, smoking history, and premature family CAD strongly point to underlying coronary artery disease.
  • It is important to exclude other potentially reversible causes such as thyroid disease, ethanol, nutritional deficiencies, primary valvular pathology and uncontrolled prolonged tachycardia.
  • The mitral regurgitation in this patient is most likely to be secondary to left ventricular dilatation and subsequent annular dilatation of the mitral valve ring. This will contribute to the development of pulmonary hypertension.

Explanation of Other Options:

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option A): Typically features normal or small ventricles with preserved systolic function and biatrial enlargement, not a dilated, low-EF ventricle.

Hypertension (Option C): Long-standing hypertension produces LV hypertrophy before dysfunction; absence of LVH on echo argues against hypertensive cardiomyopathy.

Valvular heart disease (Option D): Primary valve disease would show structural valvular abnormalities; here, mitral regurgitation is secondary to LV dilation.

choices.text: ST-segment elevation in leads II, III and aVF
Occlusion of the left circumflex artery

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in a patient with Right ventricular myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Right ventricular myocardial infarction (RVMI) usually occurs in association with an inferior-wall left ventricular infarction, as revealed by the ECG.
  • In ECG, along with ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF, which suggests an inferior wall MI, a patient with RVMI may also have ST elevation in V1 and in right-sided chest leads V3R-V6R.
  • The typical clinical findings in RVMI include bradycardia (due to AV node involvement), hypotension, raised JVP with positive Kussmaul sign (inspiratory rise of JVP). (Options C & D ruled out)
  • Hypotension is typically treated with IV fluids (0.9% saline)
  • There is usually a right coronary occlusion. Characteristic clinical features include a low cardiac output syndrome with jugular venous distension but no pulmonary vascular congestion.
  • Left circumflex artery occlusion (Option B) produces lateral-wall infarction (leads I, aVL, V5-V6), not RV MI.

choices.text: Remain elevated for up to two days after myocardial damage
Are seen in patients with NSTEMI
Can be used to distinguish Non-Q from Q MI

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true of raised cardiac troponin levels in the blood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most sensitive markers of myocardial cell damage are the cardiac troponins T and I.
  • Troponins are regulatory elements of the contractile apparatus in muscle.
  • They are released within 4-6 hours and remain elevated for up to two weeks. (Option B ruled out)
  • Troponin levels are elevated in patients with NSTEMI and STEMI, while it is normal in subjects with stable and unstable angina.
  • Cardioversion can give rise to raised creatine kinase (CK) levels due to skeletal muscle damage and mildly raised troponins in a small share of patients. (Option A ruled out)
  • Non-Q and Q MI are electrocardiographic diagnoses. Raised troponin levels indicate heart muscle damage: the commonest cause being ischaemic damage. Myocarditis or myocardial contusion can also cause raised troponin levels. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman suddenly deteriorates 2 days after receiving thrombolytic therapy for acute myocardial infarction. She complained of severe shortness of breath with an O2 saturation of 91% despite oxygen supplementation. On examination, her BP is 105/70 mmHg, with a pulse of 105/min, regular. She has an apical systolic murmur and bilateral basal crepitations. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rupture of the posteromedial papillary muscle typically occurs 2-7 days post-MI (peaking around day 2-3) and causes acute severe mitral regurgitation, manifesting as a new apical pansystolic murmur and pulmonary oedema.
  • The posteromedial papillary muscle is twice as likely to rupture as the anterolateral one because the posteromedial papillary muscle is supplied by the right coronary artery only, whereas the anterolateral papillary muscle receives supply from both the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries.
  • The murmur (apical pansystolic) is consistent with mitral regurgitation, which in turn leads to acute left ventricular failure.
  • Management is based on decreasing afterload to stabilise patients before undergoing valvular surgery; sodium nitroprusside is the usual therapy of choice where blood pressure allows.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute interventricular septal rupture (Option A): Presents with a harsh, loud holosystolic murmur and a palpable thrill at the left sternal border, plus acute VSD signs, but crepitations are less prominent.

Pericardial tamponade (Option B): Features hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad) without pansystolic murmur or pulmonary oedema.

LV wall rupture (Option C): Causes sudden tamponade and electromechanical dissociation with rapid cardiovascular collapse, not a pansystolic murmur or bilateral crepitations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who presented with sudden onset severe chest pain was detected to have bradycardia and hypotension on evaluation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inferior wall MI can lead to bradycardia and hypotension by 2 mechanisms:

  • Ischemia of the AV node:The AV nodal artery, which arises from the right coronary artery (RCA) 80% of the time, supplies blood to the AV node. In an inferior wall MI, if the RCA is occluded, it can lead to ischemia of the AV node, resulting in significant bradycardia.
  • Bezold-Jarisch reflex:This reflex is characterized by increased vagal tone secondary to ischemia. The heightened vagal activity can slow the heart rate and cause vasodilation, leading to hypotension.

Anterior wall MI may be associated with features of sympathetic overactivity like tachycardia and hypertension, while extensive anterior wall MI can lead to reduced cardiac output and hypotension.

Posterior wall MI (Option B) usually accompanies inferior MI, but isolated posterior MI does not characteristically produce profound bradycardia.

Anteroseptal MI (Option D) involves the septal perforator branches of the LAD, leading to heart block sometimes, but more often causes tachycardia from sympathetic drive.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly affected coronary artery in a patient with myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The frequency of involvement of coronaries in MI is left anterior descending artery > right coronary artery > left circumflex artery
  • LAD occlusion often produces extensive anterior myocardial injury, contributing significantly to morbidity and mortality, hence its nickname 'widowmaker.'
  • Identification of LAD involvement guides urgent reperfusion strategies, as anterior MIs carry a higher risk of pump failure and malignant arrhythmias.

Key Takeaways:

  • LAD is the most common artery involved in MI, supplying critical anterior and septal myocardium.
  • Anterior MIs from LAD occlusion necessitate rapid recognition and reperfusion to reduce high complication rates.

choices.text: 70% stenosis of left anterior descending artery
Total occlusion of left anterior descending artery
70% stenosis of left circumflex artery

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of smoking and hypertension presents to the emergency room with central crushing chest pain, nausea and sweating. On examination, his BP is 104/70 mmHg, his pulse is 105/min regular, and he looks pale, grey and sweaty.
ECG: ST elevation V1-V4, ST depression II, III and aVL
Which of the following is the most likely finding on angiography?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This man is suffering from an ST elevation anterior myocardial infarction and most likely has an occlusion of his left anterior descending artery due to plaque rupture.

Left circumflex or right coronary artery occlusions would be expected to result in either lateral or inferior ECG changes.

Management of choice is primary PCI, as early as possible after the onset of chest pain.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypothermia promotes pulmonary vasoconstriction (Option A): Unrelated to myocardial infarction and not an angiographic finding.

70% stenosis of left anterior descending artery (Option B): Significant but insufficient to produce full-thickness anterior STEMI; partial stenoses more often cause unstable angina or NSTEMI.

70% stenosis of left circumflex artery (Option D): Would produce lateral or posterior ECG changes rather than anterior lead ST elevations.

choices.text: Useful in patients with refractory chronic angina
Inhibitor of If current in the SA node cells
Administered at a dose of 500-1000 mg/day
Contraindicated in patients with QTc prolongation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Ranolazine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ranolazine inhibits the late sodium current in myocardial cells. It is contraindicated in patients with liver dysfunction and QTc prolongation.
  • It is dosed at 500 mg twice daily, which may be increased to 1,000 mg twice daily (total 1,000-2,000 mg/day) based on tolerance and symptomatic response.
  • Ranolazine is approved for patients whose symptoms persist despite first-line therapies.
  • Ivabradine helps control the heart rate by inhibiting the funny current (If) in the SA node cells.

questions.text: The most common valvular abnormality seen in a patient with acute myocardial infarction include:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The different mechanisms for occurrence of mitral regurgitation in acute MI include:

  1. Papillary muscle dysfunction due to ischemia
  2. Partial or complete rupture of chordae tendinae
  3. Papillary muscle rupture

Papillary muscle rupture is common with inferior wall MI because the posteromedial papillary muscle is involved due to a single blood supply by the posterior descending artery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aortic regurgitation (Option A): Rare in acute MI; requires primary aortic or root pathology rather than ischemic injury.

Mitral valve prolapse (Option C): A chronic degenerative condition unrelated to acute coronary events.

Aortic root dilatation (Option D): Occurs in connective tissue diseases or chronic hypertension, not acutely post-MI.

choices.text: Myoglobin is the earliest to rise following MI
CK-MB is useful in assessment of reinfarction as it returns to baseline following 48-72 hours
Troponins are more specific for MI diagnosis than Creatine kinase
The order of rise of biomarkers is CK-MB, LDH followed by troponins

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the cardiac biomarkers in myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most sensitive markers of myocardial cell damage are the cardiac troponins T and I.
  • Troponins are regulatory elements of the contractile apparatus in muscle.
  • The order of rise of cardiac biomarkers is
  • Myoglobin (2-3 hours) → CK-MB (3-6 hours) → Troponins (3-12 hours) → LDH (24 hours)
  • CK-MB levels rise by 3-6 hours, reach their peak by 12-24 hours and return to baseline by 48-72 hours. Hence, it is useful for the evaluation of a suspected reinfarction.
  • In myocardial infarction, levels of LDH 1 > 2 in plasma, which is called the 'flipped LDH' pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following pharmacological agents is most likely to benefit a patient with angina due to cardiac syndrome X?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitrates are often effective in patients with syndrome X, which is currently termed 'microvascular angina'.

  • Cardiac syndrome X consists of angina-like chest pain during exertion, characteristic ECG changes during exercise testing, normal coronary arteries on cardiac catheterisation and no inducible coronary artery spasm during catheterisation.
  • It should not be confused with metabolic syndrome X, which comprises central obesity, glucose intolerance, dyslipidemia, and high blood pressure.
  • Nitrates reduce both preload and microvascular resistance, enhancing subendocardial perfusion without relying on large epicardial artery dilation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Aspirin (Option A): An Antiplatelet agent that reduces thrombotic risk but does not address microvascular vasomotion abnormalities causing chest pain.

Bisoprolol (Option B): Beta-blockers may reduce heart rate and oxygen demand but show inconsistent benefit in microvascular angina compared to nitrates.

Diltiazem (Option C): Calcium-channel blockers relax epicardial vessels; less effective on the small arterioles implicated in syndrome X.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has effort-related angina. His total cholesterol is 212 mg/dl. He has no other cardiac risk factors and no other relevant medical history. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The choice of first-line treatment for the prophylaxis of effort-related angina in someone without contraindications is a β-Blocker.

β-Blockers also remain the choice in someone who has suffered a previous myocardial infarction.

Calcium-channel blockers - especially diltiazem and verapamil can be used, although they should be avoided in the presence of significant left ventricular dysfunction.

Nitrates are of good value, but they come after β-Blockers.

Care should be taken before combining a β-Blocker and non-dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker, especially if there is evidence of conduction disturbance or LV dysfunction.

The Scandinavian Simvastatin Survival Study showed that a statin given to patients with angina pectoris and a cholesterol level of 212-308 mg/dl significantly reduced the risk of MI.

Aspirin would also, of course, be recommended for secondary prevention of ischaemic events, and nitrates could be used for symptom relief.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most preferred modality for assessing myocardial viability?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A PET scan is considered the gold standard in myocardial viability assessment. It can assess both myocardial blood flow and metabolic activity with different radiotracers.
  • Contrast-enhanced MRI and dobutamine stress cardiac MRI also have high specificity, especially for assessing ventricular function.
  • Thallium-201 radionuclide scan (Option C): Provides perfusion imaging with some viability information via redistribution, but is less sensitive and involves higher radiation than PET.
  • Coronary CT scan (Option D): Visualises coronary anatomy but cannot assess myocardial viability.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause for elevated Troponin T?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Troponins are not elevated in a patient with stable or unstable angina.

Raised troponins are markers of myocardial injury and are present in patients with myocardial infarction.

choices.text: Aspirin, metoprolol, ramipril and a statin
Aspirin, atenolol, ramipril, furosemide and a statin
Aspirin, isosorbide mononitrate, ramipril and a statin
Aspirin, nitrate, losartan and a statin

questions.text: A 52-year-old man suffers an extensive anterior myocardial infarction but recovers well in hospital. His pre-discharge ECHO shows him to have an ejection fraction 35%. He is otherwise asymptomatic. His medications on discharge should include which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Following a myocardial infarction, patients with LV dysfunction benefit from taking β-Blockers and RAAS blockers.

There is strong evidence supporting the use of aspirin and a statin post-MI. Aspirin provides secondary prevention of thrombosis, and statins stabilise atherosclerotic plaques and lower LDL, decreasing recurrent MI risk.

Nitrates are reserved for angina relief and diuretics only for symptomatic heart failure or volume overload, neither of which this asymptomatic, euvolemic patient requires.

Diuretics are indicated for patients with symptomatic heart failure and those with fluid overload.

choices.text: Pericarditis occurring in the setting of MI
NSAIDS and steroids are used to reduce inflammation initially

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Dressler syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Dressler syndrome is a late post-MI autoimmune pericarditis arising 2-10 weeks after infarction due to immune complex deposition. Initial treatment is high-dose aspirin, not NSAIDs or corticosteroids, to avoid impairing myocardial scar healing.
  • Patients present with pleuritic chest pain relieved by leaning forward, a pericardial friction rub, low-grade fever, and elevated inflammatory markers; echocardiogram may show pericardial effusion without new LV dysfunction.
  • ECG findings include PR segment depression and ST segment elevation.
  • Adjunctive colchicine reduces recurrence risk, and corticosteroids are reserved only for refractory cases after aspirin and colchicine, given their potential to delay infarct repair.

questions.text: A 66-year-old lady, post-myocardial infarction, is suspected to have a left ventricular apical thrombus. What is the most suitable imaging technique for confirming this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most suitable imaging technique for confirming the presence of a left ventricular apical thrombus is Transthoracic Echocardiography (Option D).

  • Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE)is the initial imaging modality of choice in evaluating cardiac structure and function. It is non-invasive and can provide real-time images of the heart. In the case of a suspected left ventricular apical thrombus, TTE can visualise the thrombus directly, allowing for a reliable diagnosis.
  • Cardiac MRI (Option A):Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging is a powerful tool for assessing cardiac structure and function. While it can detect thrombi, it is typically used for more detailed evaluation after an initial diagnosis has been made, often with TTE.
  • Left Ventricular Angiography (Option B):This involves injecting contrast dye into the coronary arteries to visualise the heart's chambers. While it can detect thrombi, it's an invasive procedure, and this technique carries a risk of dislodging and embolisation of the intraventricular thrombus. So it's generally reserved for cases where other imaging methods like TTE have provided inconclusive results or when planning interventions.
  • Multiple Uptake Gated Acquisition Scanning (Option C):This is not a standard imaging technique for evaluating cardiac thrombi. It's more commonly used in nuclear medicine for assessing myocardial perfusion and function.

In summary, while multiple imaging modalities can contribute to the evaluation of cardiac thrombi, Transthoracic Echocardiography (TTE) is typically the initial and most suitable choice due to its non-invasive nature and direct visualisation capabilities.
